text: chapter number nine as we continue our series on Sunday evenings through the book of Genesis. And last week, as you'll recall, we were in the first seven verses of Genesis 9. Tonight we'll be in verses 8 through 17, Genesis 9, verses 8 through 17. And let me just bring you up to speed with those events that have transpired in leading up to the text of Scripture that we'll study this evening. Of course, at the end of chapter number 8, the Bible gives us the information that Noah and his family, they departed the ark, the animals, they came off of the ark, and God had given them the direction to do so, and God gave them that direction and they obeyed. We find the first matter of business after leaving the ark was that Noah built an altar and he made offerings unto the Lord. The Bible tells us in verse number 20 of Genesis 8 that he offered burnt offerings on the altar. We understand that God was pleased with these offerings, for it tells us in verse number 21 that the Lord smelled a sweet savor, and notice what the Bible says, and the Lord said in his heart. And what God said in his heart in verses 21 and 22, as it's recorded there at the end of Genesis chapter number 8, will really be further expounded on in the text of Scripture that we're studying this evening in verses 8 through 17. We find that the Bible says that what God said, the Lord said in his heart, I will not again curse the ground anymore for man's sake, for the imagination of man's heart is evil from his youth, neither will I against my anymore everything living as I have done. While the earth remaineth, seed time and harvest and cold and heat and summer and winter and day and night shall not cease. As we studied last week on Sunday evening, the first seven verses, God begins to provide Noah and his family with direction, instruction, if you will, for life after the flood. As they come off the ark and they make those offerings, those sacrifices unto the Lord, we find that the Lord speaks to them, God blessed Noah and his sons and said unto them, beginning in verse number 1 of chapter number 9, and gave them instruction with regard to living life after the flood. I'm thankful, as I've mentioned last week, that God has given us instruction in his word and he's given us direction for how to live our lives. It was important for Noah and his family to understand how they were to live that behavior which would please the Lord. I'm often reminded of the great truth of Ephesians 5 in verse number 10, where Paul says to the believers of Ephesus that we're to prove what is acceptable in the sight of the Lord. That's a process of studying the word of God and digging into God's word, examining the instruction that God has given us within his word to determine that which is well-pleasing, that which is acceptable in the sight of the Lord. I'm thankful that God has been faithful to give us instruction, to give us direction. Can you imagine if we had no Bible? It's a hard thought for us to even comprehend. Many that are within our congregation, and we think about, of course, even my children and young people that have been here for years, just how they've always had a Bible. They never were in a place where maybe they didn't have a Bible, they didn't have instruction, they didn't have the direction that God's given us in his word, but I'm so thankful that we've been blessed, that we have the Bible, we have the instruction, that God has been faithful to give us his word. I know I've mentioned in the past in various settings that it's not as if God is sitting back and allowing us to live life and saying, nope, that's not going to work, that's not going to cut it, that doesn't please me, no, try again. We just were aimlessly, helplessly, hopelessly trying in vain to find out what might please God. No, he's given us his word, and he tells us, these are the things that please me. You find that on many occasions, we find that the Bible tells us, even as we look at 1 Corinthians chapter 10, and use the example that Paul would give to the believers of the church in Corinth, he says, with many of them, God was not well pleased. Okay, we'll take note of that. That behavior that is mentioned did not please God, and therefore, I ought not behave in like manner. We find that God gave instruction to Noah and to his family, and what a blessing that is. We come to verse number 8, and this evening we'll look at verses 8 through 17, and if you're taking notes, this is actually lesson number 31 through the book of Genesis, believe it or not. Lesson number 31, the Noahic Covenant, the Noahic Covenant, and often we talk about the Abrahamic Covenant, and the Davidic Covenant, and those things, and this is the Noahic Covenant, and really it's captured for us in verses 8 through 17. We'll read the text of Scripture, and then get into the lesson this evening. The Bible says this in verse number 8 of Genesis 9, and God spake unto Noah and to his sons with him, saying, And I, behold, I establish My covenant with you, and with your seed after you, and with every living creature that is with you, of the fowl, of the cattle, and of every beast of the earth with you, from all that go out of the ark to every beast of the earth. And I will establish My covenant with you, neither shall all flesh be cut off any more by the waters of a flood. Neither shall there any more be a flood to destroy the earth. And God said, This is the token of the covenant which I make between Me and you, and every living creature that is with you, for perpetual generations. I do set My bow in the cloud, and it shall be for a token of a covenant between Me and the earth. And it shall come to pass when I bring a cloud over the earth, that the bow shall be seen in the cloud. And I will remember My covenant, which is between Me and you, and every living creature of all flesh. And the waters shall no more become a flood to destroy all flesh. And the bow shall be in the cloud, and I will look upon it, that I may remember the everlasting covenant between God and every living creature of all flesh that is upon the earth. And God said unto Noah, This is the token of the covenant which I have established between Me and all flesh that is upon the earth. And we speak about the rainbow. Not long ago, there was just a terrible storm that had come through our neighborhood, and Joseph and I, just shortly after, were walking through the neighborhood, and we saw a double rainbow, and it was just so vivid and so beautiful, and we took some pictures, and it was just beautiful. But when we think about the rainbow, we ought to be reminded of the Noahic covenant and understanding that this is the token that God gave to Noah and to his sons with regard to this covenant that we'll study this evening. He is the initiator. He is the one that will give the terms of the covenant. Again, He will make this reference throughout the portion of Scripture, but we find that He says here that He, with every living creature that is with you, of the fowl, of the cattle, of every beast of the earth with you, from all that go out of the ark to every beast of the earth, and we find that this covenant, we understand that God is the creator, that He's created all of the plant life, animal life, and of course, all of the animals. of course, human beings. He is the Lord God Omnipotent. He is the Creator of the universe. And He's making this covenant. You'll recall with me the death that was the result of the flood. Again, we notice throughout this covenant that this is a covenant that God is making. He's the initiator. He's the one making the details, giving the details. This is not a covenant that is conditional or dependent on anything that Noah or any of His descendants will do. This is a promise, a covenant, that God is making to His creation. There's only been one global flood. There only will ever be one global flood. And that was the flood of Noah's day.
